sub.page.title: Solving a System of Linear Equations Geometrically - Preview

block.para: Here we express, in geometrical terms, the structure of the simultaneous solutions of a system of linear equations. We recall that the solutions of a single linear equation
form a hyperplane which is perpendicular to the vector \mathbf{n}:= (a_1,\dots ,a_n).

info.caption: Illustration
info.para: Of the solution set of the linear equation
Here we assume tacitly that the normal vector \mathbf{n}:= (a_1,\dots ,a_n) is not the 0-vector.

block.para: The simultaneous solutions of two linear equations
form the intersection of two hyperplanes. When forming such an intersection of hyperplanes, one of several distinct situations can occur. Let's illustrate this for equations in 3 unknowns.

First case the normal vectors \mathbf{n}_1:= (a_1,a_2 ,a_3) and \mathbf{n}_2 := (b_1,b_2,b_3) are not parallel. Therefore, the associated hyperplanes are not parallel and, as a consequence, the simultaneous solutions of the two equations form the intersection of the two planes. It always is a line.
Second case the two hyperplanes are parallel and distinct. There is no point that belongs to both hyperplanes. Therefore there is no simultaneous solution of the given system of two linear equations.

Third case the two hyperplanes are identical. This situation is a sibling of the second case. Only this time, the solutions of one equation also solve the other. So the simultaneous solutions of the given equations form a plane.

In a system of m linear equations in n unknowns, the solutions of each one of them form a hyperplane in \RNr[n]. Therefore the simultaneous solutions of the system form exactly the intersection of all of these hyperplanes.
